parts: Identify this president of a South American country who fled to Japan in 2000 after a corruption scandal. His government employed the Grupo Colina death squad and substantially liberalized the economy.
Alberto Fujimori was president of this country, which is currently led by Ollanta Humala. After Fujimori was convicted of human rights abuses, his supporters rioted in the streets of Lima.

This terrorist attack carried out by Shining Path in 1992 led to a massive crackdown of the group by Fujimori. Two trucks, each carrying 1000 kilos of explosives, exploded in the business district of Miraflores, killing 24.
Identify this law of thermodynamics, a restatement of the conservation of energy which states that the change in internal energy is equal to the sum of heat added and work done on the system.
These devices, which include a type commonly created from a coffee cup in introductory chemistry classrooms, are used to measure the heat flow in a chemical reaction.
This type of calorimeter consists of a namesake highly pressurized reaction vessel of constant volume enclosed within a larger chamber full of water. The reaction is usually begun using fuse wire.
Identify this woodcut which shows an angel resting his head on his hand, sitting next to a polyhedron and a building with a magic square inscribed on it.
Melancholia I is a work by this German Renaissance artist, who is also famous for a series of self-portraits and for a biologically incorrect depiction of a rhinoceros.

Both Durer and this other German printmaker created a depiction of the Ecce Homo scene. His depiction of St Anthony in mid-air surrounded by demons was believed to have inspired Michelangelo's work on the same subject.
Identify this series of novels that includes Spring Snow and the Decay of the Angel centering on Shigekuni Honda's repeated attempts to save his repeatedly reincarnating friend.

The Sea of Fertility tetralogy was written by this tortured Japanese author, who wrote about the stammering vengeful misfit Mizoguchi burning down the title structure in his Temple of the Golden Pavillion.
This is the friend of Shigekuni Honda who is successively reincarnated as an anti-government plotter, a Thai princess, and a violent orphan.

answers: Reflections on the Revolution in France, and on the Proceedings in Certain Societies in London Relative to That Event
Letters on a Regicide Peace or Two Letters Addressed to A Member of the Present Parliament, on the Proposals for Peace with the Regicide Directory of France
parts: Identify this long essay framed as a letter to an unnamed correspondent, which ends by praising the entire system set up by the British constitution, to which we owe "our happy situation."
Reflections on the Revolution in France was written by this erstwhile Corey Robin punching bag and prominent British conservative.

Burke also published two missives intended to persuade the British government to not make peace with the Directory; they are collected under this name, indicating the allegedly criminal nature of the French government.

answers: The Winter's Tale [do not accept "A Winter's Tale"]
parts: Name this play in which King Leontes jealously imprisons his wife Hermione, but then takes her back in the fifth act when she reappears posing as a statue.
This lost daughter of Leontes and Hermione is raised as a shepherd. She eventually marries Prince Florizel.
It's unknown today whether the original productions of The Winter's Tale used a real or fake one of these animals. A famous stage command in the play is "exit, pursued by" one of these.
This semi-legendary figure, whose real name is believed to be Mary Ludwig Hays, received her nickname because she served as a water-carrier. After her husband collapsed, she took over his cannon.

Molly Pitcher's actions occurred at this 1778 battle, which occurred after von Steuben had grilled and trained Washington's men at Valley Forge. Charles Lee and Washington managed to fight Cornwallis' forces to a draw.
This 16-year-old New York resident undertook a famous night ride to alert troops that the British were coming. She's often called the female Paul Revere, though her journey was twice as long as his.
Identify this oratorio about some Jewish rebels, which includes the air "Pious orgies," and the chorus "See, the conquering hero comes."
Judas Maccabaeus was written by this German-British composer of Messiah and Israel in Egypt. ANSWER: George Frideric Handel
This other work by Handel is a setting of a John Dryden poem written to celebrate Saint Cecilia's Day, and is noted for the arias "Bacchus, ever fair" and "Revenge, Timotheus cries."

answers: horizontal gene transfer or lateral gene transfer
parts: Identify this adjective that describes traits that derive from a common ancestor. The human arm, whale fin, and bat wing are some examples.

A specific type of homologous structures, called orthologs, are separated by a speciation event. This type of speciation occurs when a population is divided by some kind of physical or geographic barrier.

The creation of phylogenetic trees by homology is complicated by the existence of these processes, in which an organism incorporates genetic material of another without being related. Conjugation is one example.
Name this Italian film director whose La Notte tells the story of one day in the life of Giovanni and Lidia's dissolving marriage.

This Antonioni film, to which La Notte is the spiritual successor, opens when Anna, Claudia, and Sandro go on a yachting trip, only for Anna to disappear. The focus then shifts to the romance between Claudia and Sandro as Anna's mysterious disappearance is left unresolved.
This other Italian, a contemporary of Antonioni, told the story of the aimless journalist Marcello in La Dolce Vita and of Gelsomina's journey with a traveling strongman in La Strada.

answers: On the Law of War and Peace or De jure belli ac pacis
Hugo Grotius or Hugo de Groot
parts: Identify this three-volume work that classifies just wars as those for self-defense, reparation of injury, or punishment. It is the foundation for much of international law.
On the Law of War and Peace was written by this Dutch jurist and philosopher, who defended his faith in his On the Truth of the Christian Religion.

Grotius also discussed a natural theory of these. Dworkin wrote a positivist work titled after taking them seriously, and in several documents they are said to be imbued to humanity by a creator and to be unalienable.

answers: Parthian Shot [do not accept Parting Shot]
parts: Name this military technique named for a Middle Eastern people that notably employed it.
The Parthian shot was a major tactic in this Parthian victory over the Romans. Surena, the Parthian General, employed large numbers of Camels in this battle to replenish supplies for his archers.

The Roman Commander at Carrhae, Marcus Licinius Crassus, was brutally murdered during the negotiations following the battle and then had this substance poured down his throat, though some sources say that action was the cause of death.
Identify these scary spirits of vengeance from Greek mythology, who had snakes in their hair and eyes that dripped blood. They especially pursued people who murdered family members.

The Furies chased after this son of Agammemnon and Clytemnestra after he killed his mother, but Athena gets him off the hook. This sister of Electra and Iphigenia is the subject of a cycle of plays by Aeschylus.
Orestes
Identify this public-key cryptosystem which uses the product of two prime numbers to generate a public and a private key.

The RSA algorithm relies on a "little" theorem named for this French mathematician. Andrew Wiles proved a result named after this mathematician which states that x to the n plus y to the n equals z to the n has no solutions in integers for n greater than 2.

Cryptography problems often involve these two generic people passing messages back and forth to each other. Sometimes a figure named Eve tries to intercept the messages, and physics problems like these two people also.
Name this Jewish author of Herzog and The Adventures of Augie March.
This other novel by Bellow describes the journey of Eugene, the title character, through Africa, during which he moves a statue of the goddess Mummah and becomes a spiritual leader of the Wariri.

In this other Bellow novel, Albert Corde, the title character, travels from Chicago to attend to his dying mother in law and in doing so gets the opportunity to witness a totalitarian state first hand.

answers: Adar [accept Adar II or Adar Bet]
parts: Name this Jewish Holiday, the story of which is recounted in the Megillat Ester.

The primary antagonist of the Purim story is this man, who attempts to get Mordecai and the rest of the Jews killed but is eventually hanged in the gallows he had had built for Mordecai. He is considered the archetypal persecutor of the Jews.
Purim is celebrated in this last month of the Hebrew Calendar. In leap years, a month with the same name is added prior to this month.

answers: alpha or Linear Coefficient of Thermal Expansion
parts: Name this number which is the ratio between the percentage change in length of a material and the absolute temperature change in Kelvins.
When treating the sides of a cube as lines affected by the linear coefficient of expansion, the resulting volumetric coefficient of expansion is this factor times alpha.

This process is governed by Fourier's law which states that the rate of this process is proportional to the negative gradient of the temperature and to the cross sectional area of the material. It is the method by which heat flows through solids.
Name this group of Protestant Agrarian communists that practiced communal farming and advocated egalitarian living, which was founded by Gerrard Winstanley.
The Diggers were a dissenting group that arose during this conflict between Roundheads and Cavaliers.

This commander-in-chief of the parliamentarian forces and associate of Oliver Cromwell during the English Civil War confronted the Diggers at St. George's Hill but ascertained they were doing no harm.

answers: The Pretentious Young Ladies [or The Affected Young Ladies, or Les PrÃ©cieuses ridicules]
The School for Wives [or L'Ã‰cole des Femmes]
parts: Name this satire in which Cathos and Magdelon put on airs of sophistication for their debut in Paris.
This playwright of The Pretentious Young Ladies would have played Mascarille in the first few productions. He also wrote Tartuffe and The Misanthrope.
In this other play, Moliere would have played the pompous Arnolphe, who tries to raise AgnÃ¨s for his wife without exposing her to the ways of the world.

Identify this group of hackers, which recently attacked the US Department of Justice website after megaupload was shut down by the government. They also attacked PayPal after it froze WikiLeaks' account in 2010.
Anonymous' most famous attack is undoubtedly the one against this organization, during which they posted a really creepy youtube video criticizing this L. Ron Hubbard-founded "church".
Anonymous typically uses this kind of attack, in which a group of computers repeatedly ping or make data requests to the target server until it chokes to death.
